abstract.para: The Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002 ("FISMA", 44 U.S.C. ยง 3541, et seq.) is a U.S. federal law enacted in 2002 as Title III of the E-Government Act of 2002 (Pub.L. 107-347, 116 Stat. 2899). The U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) publishes the recommended security controls for Federal Information Systems and Organizations.

para.literallayout: 25 Total number of line items in guideline 24 Items at least partially addressed by OS Lockdown 1 Items not addressed by OS Lockdown

table.title: Guideline name/description for NIST FISMA SP 800-53

row.entry: Permitted Actions w/o Identification or Authentication
Access Control for Portable and Mobile Systems
Audit and Accountability Policy and Procedures

table.title: Module to line item breakdown for NIST FISMA SP 800-53

entry.xref: Deny NFS Client Access Without UID or GID
Enable Strong TCP Sequence Number Generation
Ignore ICMP ECHO and TIMESTAMP Requests
Limit Access To Root From Su
Lock account after three failed login attempts
Name Service Switch Configuration File Permissions
Remove Insecure_Locks option for NFS Server
Restrict Use of Traceroute and Ping
SSHD Set Idle Timeout Interval for User Logins
Set Password Aging on Active Accounts
Set X Screen Saver Application Defaults
